persona.name: Mateo Javier Ramos

occupation.title: Student
occupation.description: Full-time student in 9th grade. Primary responsibilities include attending classes, completing homework, participating in group projects, preparing for statewide assessments, and representing the school on the junior varsity soccer team. Outside school hours he helps at home with chores, sometimes helps tutor younger cousins in math, and volunteers at his church's summer program once or twice per year. He is not in the labor force (no formal job), though he does occasional paid babysitting or yard work for neighbors during summer. Skills relevant to school role: time management for homework, teamwork from sports, basic coding logic, bilingual communication, and public speaking from class presentations.

persona.education: Currently a 9th grade student at Jefferson Early High School (public school in San Antonio). Mostly A-B student with stronger performance in mathematics and social studies than in advanced language arts. Participates in school Spanish Heritage Club and is on the junior varsity soccer team. Has completed 8th grade with recognition for good attendance and a classroom leadership award. Takes an introductory computer-science elective (block-based coding and basic Python concepts). Home life supports Spanish and English bilingual development; family expects him to help with younger cousins occasionally.
long_term_goals: Graduate high school with enough GPA and test scores to get a scholarship to a state university.
Study engineering (civil or mechanical) or computer science so he can get a stable job and help his parents financially.
Be the first in his immediate family to earn a college degree.
Own a reliable car and move into a modest apartment near campus while staying close to family.
Keep close ties with extended family and preserve cultural traditions (celebrations, language).
Travel to Mexico to visit grandparents’ hometown and connect with extended relatives.
Play competitive soccer recreationally into adulthood and possibly coach youth teams.
Learn to DJ and produce music as a creative side skill.
Build small tech projects (apps or hardware prototypes) to solve everyday problems in his community.
Be emotionally available to his future partner and avoid repeating mistakes he sees in relationships around him.
persona.style: Casual, colloquial, and warm; switches fluidly between English and Spanish (Spanglish) depending on the listener. Speech is quick when excited and soft when embarrassed; uses slang common among urban Texas teens mixed with family Spanish idioms ("¡órale!", "¿Qué onda?", "dale"). Typical mannerisms: tucks hair behind his ear when nervous, speaks with his hands when excited, laughs by covering his mouth, and uses nicknames for people (e.g., "Tío", "Mamá"). Prefers hoodies, sneakers, and soccer jerseys. On social media (primarily Instagram and TikTok) he posts short soccer clips and memes; when speaking to teachers or older adults he becomes more polite and slightly formal, using "sir/ma'am" and smoothing over slang. Values loyalty and humility in his tone; when upset he goes quiet, avoids eye contact and fiddles with a bracelet or shoelace. Comfortable giving short presentations, but public speaking for long periods causes visible anxiety (fidgeting, fast speech). Has an easy laugh, a habit of repeating a phrase for emphasis ("for real, for real"), and often asks clarifying questions like "So what does that mean?" He occasionally writes quick doodles in the margins of notebooks and quotes soccer players or musicians to express mood.

traits: Curious — likes to take things apart mentally and physically to understand how they work.
Loyal — highly protective of close friends and family.
Practical — prefers concrete solutions and step-by-step plans.
Playful — enjoys joking around and teasing his friends affectionately.
Reserved with strangers — slow to trust new adults but warm with peers.
Competitive — driven during games and class contests, hates giving up.
Anxious about big transitions (tests, moving grades, college decisions).
Empathetic — notices when friends are upset and will try to help.
Impulsive in small ways — buys snacks or makes late-night plans without thinking through consequences.
Persevering — when motivated, will work late nights to finish a project.
Pragmatic idealist — wants real change (help family, community) but chooses practical steps.
Sentimental — holds onto mementos (concert wristband, handwritten notes).

big_five.openness: Moderate-High. Enjoys new music, learning about how things work, and experimenting with basic coding and music apps; not drawn to abstract art but curious about cultures and ideas.
big_five.conscientiousness: Moderate. Generally responsible with homework and sports practice but can procrastinate on long-term projects and get distracted by friends or phone.
big_five.extraversion: Medium. Sociable and warm with peers, performs confidently on the soccer field, but needs quiet time after intense socializing.
big_five.agreeableness: High. Cooperative and helpful, often mediates small conflicts among friends and supports family obligations.
big_five.neuroticism: Medium-High. Experiences worry about grades, family money, and future choices; prone to self-doubt and occasional sleeplessness before tests or games.

interests: Soccer: playing striker or winger — tracks MLS and local high school leagues.
Music: reggaetón, Latin pop, hip-hop, and beatmaking; enjoys making short mixes on his phone.
Soccer players he admires: Lionel Messi (a role model), Javier 'Chicharito' Hernández, local MLS players.
Technology: enjoys tinkering with old phones, learning basic Python, and using Raspberry Pi kits at school.
Video games: FIFA series, Rocket League, and occasional mobile strategy games.
Food: loves carne asada tacos, pan dulce for breakfast, and street elotes (Mexican-style corn).
Movies/TV: likes sports films (Remember the Titans), coming-of-age dramas, and family comedies.
Graphic art and doodling: draws logos, soccer plays, and graffiti-style lettering.
School clubs: Spanish Heritage Club and Robotics Club (attends meetings when schedule allows).
Social media: primarily Instagram for visuals and TikTok for short humor/music videos.
Hanging out: neighborhood basketball court, local park, and community center.
Friends: close-knit group of 6 classmates he trusts for schoolwork and free time.
Language: proud of bilingual ability; favors expressions that blend Spanish/English.
Cars: fascinated by older Hondas and pickup trucks his uncles drive.
Travel: wants to visit family in Mexico, and is curious about Los Angeles music scene.
Clothes: hoodies, soccer jerseys, Nike/Adidas sneakers; prefers comfortable streetwear.
School subjects: favorite is algebra and physics topics; dislikes repetitive busywork.
Helping others: enjoys tutoring younger cousins in math and showing kids soccer drills.
DIY: likes small home projects like fixing a loose bike chain or cleaning/organizing a garage.
Humor: enjoys sarcastic jokes, memes, and playful teasing among friends.
Streaming: watches soccer highlights and player interviews on YouTube.
Collectibles: keeps a small stack of soccer cards and stickers.
Photography: likes taking candid shots with his phone during games and family events.
Podcasts: listens to short sports and music culture podcasts on the bus.
School events: enthusiastic about pep rallies and community fundraisers.
Dance: knows basic cumbia steps and copies dance moves from TikTok.
Languages: practices formal Spanish phrases with abuela and English idioms at school.
Celebrations: participates actively in quinceañera preparations for cousins.
Comics: reads superhero comics occasionally with friends.
Volunteering: enjoys helping at the church bake sale and neighborhood clean-ups.
Entrepreneurial curiosity: interested in small side hustles like reselling shoes or running a snack stand at soccer tournaments.
likes: Carne asada tacos with extra cilantro and lime.
Late afternoon soccer practice when the air cools down.
Listening to his playlist while doing homework (instrumental or reggaetón remixes).
Posting short soccer clips on Instagram and getting feedback from friends.
Family gatherings where abuela cooks and tells stories in Spanish.
Sneakers with good grip for dribbling.
School math puzzles and competitive problem-solving activities.
Hoodies with meaningful logos (team crest, local brands).
The thrill of scoring a goal in a tight match.
Collecting limited-edition soccer cards with teammates.
Watching MLS highlights and discussing plays with friends.
Helping younger kids learn a basic soccer trick — enjoys teaching.
Making quick beat loops on his phone to accompany TikTok videos.
Paying attention to small details (a coach’s tip, a teacher’s feedback).
Walking to the corner store with friends after practice.
Going to mass occasionally with family during holidays.
The smell of fresh tortillas and coffee in the morning.
Using Spanglish jokes that get immediate laughs from bilingual peers.
Saving a portion of money given from relatives for future needs.
Finding bargains and deals at thrift stores for unique clothes.
Listening to his mom’s stories about how she immigrated and worked hard.
Playing FIFA with his cousins on long family visits.
Wearing a friendship bracelet from his girlfriend on game days for luck.
Seeing incremental progress in a coding project.
Short naps after school that rejuvenate him for practice.
A clean pair of cleats before a match.
The pride of carrying family responsibilities in small but meaningful ways.
Good tutoring sessions where a concept clicks.
The supportive clap from his parents and older cousins in the stands.
dislikes: Long, unstructured busywork that doesn't feel meaningful.
Teachers who assign group work but let others slack off.
People who are disrespectful to elders or family members.
Overpriced snacks when he has to budget his allowance.
Rude referees during close soccer matches.
Bullies or teasing that goes too far.
Classrooms that are too quiet or too noisy in ways that disrupt concentration.
Being late to practice because of missed buses or chores.
When his phone battery dies mid-clip recording.
Sophisticated gourmet food that doesn't taste like home cooking.
Any suggestion that bilingualism is less valuable than monolingual English.
Watching teammates give up early in a match.
Cramped, uncomfortable shoes for long days.
Having to explain family financial struggles to classmates.
Stereotyping of Hispanic kids as only good at sports or only a single thing.
When people appropriate Spanish words without understanding context.
Cold, rainy days that cancel outdoor practice plans.
Being excluded from group hangouts without explanation.
When an important text from a friend goes unanswered and causes misunderstandings.
Long commutes that cut into homework and sleep time.

beliefs: Education is the clearest path to a better life for him and his family.
Family obligations come first — helping parents and younger relatives matters.
Being bilingual is an advantage that connects him to more opportunities and people.
Hard work and persistence pay off, especially in small, steady steps.
Respect for elders and family customs is important even when negotiating modern life.
Money is a source of security; small savings add up and are essential.
College is attainable if he can secure scholarships and maintain grades.
Sports teach discipline, teamwork, and coping with disappointment.
Community spaces like the park and community center are vital for neighborhood youth.
Police and authority figures are complex; some are helpful, others can be biased — he judges by experience.
Religion (Catholic traditions) offers comfort in crises, but personal faith can be flexible.
Immigration stories in his family are a source of pride and humility.
Cultural identity should be preserved even while succeeding in mainstream U.S. institutions.
Friends should be loyal and honest, but healthy boundaries are necessary.
Success does not mean forgetting where you come from.
Young people should have a voice in school decisions like clubs and schedules.
Technology can be a tool for learning and income, but screen time must be balanced.
TikTok and Instagram can be useful for creativity and networking if used responsibly.
Mental health is real; it's okay to ask for help when stressed.
Mistakes are opportunities to learn; embarrassment is temporary.
Respect and consent matter in romantic relationships; "no" must be respected.
Everyone deserves basic respect regardless of immigration status, race, or religion.
Hard physical work should be valued alongside intellectual work.
Teachers who care and explain things differently make a huge difference in student success.
Local politics affect funding for schools, parks, and community programs — that matters.
Clubs and extracurriculars are as important as grades in building college applications and self-confidence.
Role models matter; seeing people from similar backgrounds succeed motivates him.
He believes he can change small things in his community, like organizing a neighborhood clean-up.
It's important to maintain cultural foods, language, and ceremonies even as life modernizes.
Romantic relationships should be respectful, honest, and not rushed — trust is built over time.
Loans and debt are intimidating; he'd prefer scholarships and saving to borrow less.
Networking through family friends and church is a practical method to find future internships or jobs.
skills: Bilingual (English-Spanish) with strong conversational fluency and the ability to switch registers depending on context (informal Spanglish with friends, more formal Spanish with abuela).
Soccer skills: ball control, dribbling in tight spaces, quick passing, awareness of wing positions, basic defending and goal-scoring instincts.
Basic coding literacy: block coding platforms (Scratch), introductory Python concepts (variables, loops), and the ability to follow online tutorials to create simple scripts.
Basic beat-making and audio editing on mobile apps (arranging loops, layering percussion).
Time management for schoolwork and practice through a simple calendar system and checklists.
Public-speaking basics: presenting class projects clearly for 5–10 minutes, using visuals and speaking notes.
Peer tutoring: can explain algebraic expressions and fractions to younger students in plain language.
Problem-solving and troubleshooting of everyday mechanical issues (bike chain, simple electronics troubleshooting).
Social media content creation: short video editing, captions, basic filters, and choosing hashtags.
Team leadership: motivating teammates during matches and calming tensions after mistakes.
Basic first aid knowledge (scrapes, ice packs, handling cramps) from sports coaches and school health classes.
Household responsibilities: cooking simple meals (rice, eggs, quesadillas), doing laundry, and helping with grocery lists.
Negotiation and interpersonal communication with neighbors, teachers, and stores.
Attention to visual detail for doodling and small design tweaks.
Adaptive learning: responds quickly to coaching tips and adjusts play within a match.
Budgeting small amounts of allowance and gifts for prioritized savings.
Baking basic pan dulce-inspired sweet breads with guidance from abuela.
Navigation of local transit routes and bus schedules to get to school and games.
Organizing small events: helped coordinate a cousin’s birthday soccer mini-tournament.
Photography basics: framing, candid shots, and simple editing on a phone app.

general: Code-switches between English and Spanish depending on the person he’s talking to.
Fiddles with a braided friendship bracelet when nervous or thinking.
Sends short, emoji-laden group texts to coordinate with friends before games.
Arrives early to warm up and prefers a 20-minute individual warm-up routine.
Frequently checks phone for messages after school and before bed.
Offers to carry groceries or help with small tasks for his mother when available.
Compliments teammates when they make good plays and is quick to apologize after a mistake.
Maintains a small savings envelope at home for goal items like cleats or concert tickets.
Keeps a few printed photos in his notebook (game highlights, cousins) as sentimental anchors.
Laughs loudest at inside jokes with his core friend group.

morning: Wakes around 6:30–7:00 AM on school days, usually to the sound of his mother calling in Spanish.
Quick breakfast: pan dulce or a toasted tortilla with cheese and a thermos of coffee or milk for himself.
Helps get a younger cousin ready for school two mornings a week.
Walks or takes the city bus to school with two friends, trading music recommendations en route.
Reviews the day’s schedule and homework during the bus ride.
schoolday: Attends classes from 8:00 AM to 3:00 PM with a 30–40 minute lunch break where he socializes with friends.
Uses free period or lunch to rehearse short presentations or to catch up on homework.
After-school: soccer practice for 90 minutes, including drills, small-sided games, and conditioning.
Returns home by 6:00–6:30 PM, showers, and eats dinner with family while talking about the day.
Spends 60–90 minutes on homework and a short session on a coding lesson or music app.
Posts a short soccer highlight or a meme on social media before bedtime.
evening: Family dinner around 7:00 PM where Spanish is often the primary language.
Sometimes helps clean up after dinner and checks in on abuela.
Wind-down routine includes a quick YouTube video or 20 minutes of a favorite playlist, then lights out around 10:00–10:30 PM on school nights.
If there’s a game the next day, goes to bed earlier and lays out gear.
weekend: Saturday morning pick-up games at the park or extra training session.
Helps with household chores and grocery runs with mother on Sunday mornings.
Family afternoon visits to extended relatives or attendance at a community event.
Occasional evening hangouts with friends at the corner store or park, returning home by 9:30–10:30 PM.
Squeezes in coding practice, a podcast episode, or beat-making to relax.

health.physical: Generally healthy and active; good stamina for soccer. Vaccinations up to date per pediatric records. Slight seasonal allergies (runny nose, watery eyes) treated with over-the-counter antihistamines as needed. Mild childhood asthma history — had an inhaler prescription in early childhood but uses it rarely now; carries a spacer at home and attends chest-check visits when recommended.
health.mental: Occasional test anxiety and worry about family finances and future; experiences brief periods of low mood after disappointments (lost game, poor grade) but no history of major depressive episodes. Has good social support from family and friends. Uses coping strategies like listening to music, talking to his girlfriend or best friend, and going for runs.
health.nutrition: Home-cooked meals are common; sometimes eats fast food with friends when budgets allow. Generally balanced but sometimes eats late-night snacks before bed.
health.sleep: Averages 8–9 hours on good nights; sleep disturbed before exams or big matches (difficulty falling asleep, racing thoughts).
health.medical_history: No chronic illnesses beyond childhood asthma; minor sports sprains (ankle) managed with home care and occasional physiotherapy advice from coach. No hospitalizations beyond routine childhood care.

relationships.name: Isabela "Isa" Morales
relationships.description: 13–14 years old, classmate he met in middle school and started dating casually six months ago. Relationship is affectionate and respectful; they exchange notes, attend school events together, and sometimes study together. They hold hands at school and call each other pet names ("Isa," "Mati"). Family knows of her and approves; she is from a neighboring family, also bilingual, and helps keep him grounded when he's anxious. They are not sexually active and emphasize trust and friendship.

relationships.name: María Ramos
relationships.description: Early 40s, works part-time as a childcare assistant at a local center. Spanish-dominant but comfortable in English. Very hands-on, warm, stern when needed, and expects Mateo to be respectful and contribute at home. She manages household budgeting carefully and saves small amounts monthly. Encourages Mateo's education and volunteers at his school events.

relationships.name: Carlos Ramos
relationships.description: Mid-40s, full-time warehouse associate/driver with a local distribution company. Hard-working, practical, sometimes tired after long shifts but supportive. Emphasizes punctuality and responsibility. Coaches some weekend soccer practice informally and demonstrates basic mechanical skills that Mateo admires.

relationships.name: Abuela (Teresa)
relationships.description: Lives nearby and is an important emotional anchor. Speaks primarily Spanish, shares family stories, teaches traditional recipes, and insists on family gatherings during holidays.

relationships.name: Sofía Ramos
relationships.description: Often spends afternoons with Mateo; he helps with homework and teaches her soccer drills. He enjoys being a mentor figure to her.

relationships.name: Core friend group (group name: "La Banda")
relationships.description: Group of 5–6 classmates who hang out after school, play FIFA, and coordinate for weekend games. They share inside jokes and support each other academically and socially.

relationships.name: Coach Hernandez
relationships.description: High school coach who encourages Mateo's development, gives constructive feedback and sometimes connects him with summer clinics. Serves as a mentor and occasional reference for volunteer opportunities.

relationships.name: Ms. Alvarez
relationships.description: Recognizes Mateo's potential, gives him extra problems to stretch his skills, and provides recommendations for academic programs.

relationships.name: Neighborhood aunt/uncle network
relationships.description: A web of relatives and close friends who provide informal child supervision, small loans or help in emergencies, and job lead-sharing when Mateo is older.

other_facts: Born and raised in San Antonio to parents who immigrated from Jalisco, Mexico; second-generation in the U.S.
Family household income falls in the $25,000–$49,999 band; finances are tightly managed and every major purchase is discussed as a family.
Household Spanish is spoken often at home, especially during family meals and visits with abuela; Mateo switches to English at school.
Celebrates a blend of Catholic traditions and secular family customs — attends mass on major holidays but isn’t obligated weekly.
Has no children.
Started playing soccer at age 5 in a community league; soccer has been a central identity-shaper.
Keeps a small notebook of game notes, song ideas, and doodles in his backpack.
Won a small soccer medal at a local tournament at age 11; it’s still taped inside his locker.
Helped organize a small neighborhood cleanup last summer with friends and earned community-service recognition from his school.
Was the first in his immediate family to be assigned to the school robotics intro class and enjoyed building a simple line-following robot.
Has a close memory of his first concert — a local teen band — and keeps the wristband in his notebook.
Often babysits his younger cousin for small paid amounts when his mother works extra shifts.
His favorite childhood meal is abuela’s mole on special Sundays; associates it with warmth and safety.
Remembers his father's long shifts at the warehouse and the promise his parents made to save for college.
His parents encouraged bilingualism deliberately; his mother corrected grammar gently and his father told stories about their hometown in Mexico.
Experienced a brief scare with asthma at age 7 on a family trip; after that his parents were attentive to symptoms and follow-up care.
First crush was in 6th grade; that experience taught him to communicate feelings more clearly and respectfully.
Has a small ritual of touching his cleats three times before stepping onto the field for luck (habit picked up from an older cousin).
Attended a cousin's quinceañera last year and helped with music and crowd seating — enjoyed the sense of family scale.
He once fixed an old MP3 player with guidance from his uncle and felt proud of learning a technical fix.
Has a mildly superstitious belief that wearing his father's old baseball cap to away matches brings good luck.
Fears letting his family down financially; this motivates his academic efforts.
Keeps a secret playlist of slower acoustic songs he listens to when he needs to calm down; no one in his friend group knows about this preference.
Enjoys making small side profits by reselling discounted sneakers online with the supervision of an older cousin.
Knows how to navigate the local bus system to get to friends' houses and occasionally uses rideshare with parental permission.
Once won a classroom leadership award after organizing a study group that improved several peers’ quiz scores.
Has been teased once for mispronouncing an English word in front of a class; the incident made him more careful but also more resilient.
He has an older cousin who recently got a welding apprenticeship and serves as a tangible example of alternate career paths besides college.
Values a simple keepsake: a small wooden soccer ball keychain given by his father the day he joined the high school team.
Dreams occasionally in Spanish and English interchangeably—his inner dialogue naturally mixes both languages.
Participated in a school exchange day where he shadowed a local community college lab and found the equipment interesting and inspiring.
Preferred childhood nickname "Mati" is used affectionately by family and girlfriend.
Has a recurring good-luck handshake ritual with his best friend before every match.
Worries about rising college costs; follows scholarship pages and attends school counselor meetings when available.
Is learning to balance cultural expectations (helping at home) and personal ambitions (after-school commitments).
Has a memorable summer memory helping his dad re-tile a bathroom — learned practical skills and gained appreciation for manual work.
Was once chosen to read a short passage in Spanish at a school cultural assembly and felt proud to represent his heritage.
Often imagines future homeownership for his parents as a motivating, long-term family goal.
Has a friendly rivalry with a neighboring school’s top winger, which pushes him to train harder.
Knows many extended relatives by first name because family gatherings are frequent and valued.
Carries a folded dollar bill in his wallet as an emergency and sentimental token from a trip with dad.
Is sensitive to political conversations at home about immigration policy; listens and forms questions about fairness and opportunity.
Has an ambition to coach younger kids in soccer to give back to the community that supported him.
